About 1927.

'ASSUMING STREET TO BE NORTH AND SOUTH'

South Street, west side, north from and including Wall Street. Also shown, is Wall Street, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of South Street. To-day (1937), a large office building, No. 120 Wall Street, stands on the area, shown in the foreground. February 23, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

Wall Street, west, from but not including South Street. 1929.

Ewing Galloway.

World's highest skyscraper of the week.
A new view of the magnificent downtown skyline, showing in center the Bank of Manhattan Company Building under construction. When complete this building will be the world's tallest skyscraper-68 stories-but not for long because of the recently anounced plans for the buildings of 100 and 150 stories. At right is 120 Wall Stree and at left is the Whitehall Building.
1929? 			Underwood and Underwood
title: General view - [Manhattan - Downtown skyline.]

text:
(1)
East River, from Battery Park (left) to John Street, showing the skyline of Lower Manhattan and faintly visible from (left to right) the U.S. Barge Office, the Staten Island and South Brooklyn Ferry landings and pier 4.
June 23, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same; at a later date and showing the change of the skyline. On the extreme right is seen the American Sugar Refining Co. Building (120 Wall Street), the 60 Wall Street Tower (under construction) and the Bank of Manhattan Building.
September 1, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, at a still later date. The Municipal Building is visible on the extreme right, and the U.S. Assay Office (low building) in the center. To the left of the Bank of Manhattan Building appears the City Bank Farmers Trust Co. Building. The point of vantage is pier 22, Porto Rico Line, Brooklyn.
July 2, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.
title: East River - Shore and skyline of lower Manhattan - South Ferry - Williamsburg Bridge - Battery Park - John Street.

General View--Lower Manhattan, East Side: Looking north and northeast from Wall Street across the slum area of the Lower East Side. In view 1 can be seen the Manhattan ends of the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges and South Street (right) The Third Avenue "El" can be seen running north in the center of the view.

P. L. Sperr

View 1: 1930
View 2: 1933

title: General view - East side of Lower Manhattan.

text:
120 Wall Street, (American Sugar Refining Building). South Street, west side, from Wall to Pine Streets. (general view north-ward).

A set of 3 views up the marginal zone that borders the East River (right) and showing in the background approaching same, the Brooklyn and the Manhattan Bridges. To the right is South Street, with its piers. The construction activity in the foreground and upon same is for the tunnel under the water that the City is driving for the Eighth Avenue Subway Line. Paralleling South Street are Front and Water Streets.

View: 1 October 3, 1930
Views: 2 and 3 October 22, 1930

P. L. Sperr

title: General view - Wall Street - North.

text:
120 Wall Street, (American Sugar Refining Building); - South Street, west side, from Wall to Pine Streets, (general view northward).

A set of 3 views photographed in the general direction of Broadway and showing upon same the Equitable, Transportation and Woolworth Buildings. To the left is Wall Street and thru the center runs Pearl Street. In View 1 appears the cleared area upon which will rise the 67 storied, 60 Wall Tower. The new structure to the right is the 22 storied, No. 1 Cedar Street Co. plant (smokestacks shown) one to the foot of the New York Steam Co. plant (smokestacks shown) one sees another new structure under construction. This is the 35 story, No. 1 Platt Street. To the west and in the same block close observance will note the excavation for another insurance center building, the 28 story No. 90 John Street Building. The two high buildings forming a backdrop are over the 25 story Insurance Central and the 14 story National Board of Fire Underwriters.

To the right and partially obscured by the stacks is the 26 story building, No. 111 John Street.

P. L. Sperr

October 3, 1930
Views: 1-2-3

title: General view - Wall Street - Northwest.

text:
120 Wall Street, (American Sugar Refining Building), South, Street, west side from Wall to Pine Streets, (general view northwest ward).

A set of two views showing the rising insurance center of lower Manhattan. This district is adjoining to the north and closely allied to the Wall Street financial houses and corporations.

In the center are the smoke stacks of the New York Steam Co. plant obscuring as it were, the aforementioned zone. Thru same appears the 26 storied building No. 111 John Street.

The new construction, shown in two stages, only three weeks apart, is the 35 storied building, No. 1 Platt Street. At the westerly end of the same block, close observation will note the excavation for the 28 story, No. 90 John Street (also No. 15 Platt Street). Forming a backdrop for the latter (opposite side of Gold Street) are the 25 and 14 story buildings that are respectively, the Insurance Center Building and the National Board of Fire Underwriters Building.

View: 1 Oct. 3, 1930
View: 2 Oct. 22, 1930

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - Wall Street - Northwest

The new construction, shown in two stages, only three weeks apart, is the 35 storied building, No. 1 Platt Street. At the westerly end of the same block, close observation will note the excavation for the 28 story, No. 90 John Street (also No. 15 Platt Street). Forming a backdrop for the latter (opposite side of Gold Street) are the 25 and 14 story buildings that are respectively, the Insurance Center Building and the National Board of Fire Underwriters Building.

title: General view - Wall Street - Northwest

text:
120 Wall Street, (American Sugar Refining Building): South Street, west side, from Wall to Pine Streets, (panoramic view northwestward).

These two views placed end to end form an arrangement of the Front, Water and Pearl Street areas. The first of these thoroughfares is in the foreground, the second thru the center, the last across the top.

Upon the west side, of the latter, appear two building construction projects. That to the left is for the new 60 Wall Tower, and that to the right, for the 35 story insurance center building No. 1 Platt Street. To the right, and thru the smokestacks of the New York Steam Co. plant, one sees the recently completed 26 storied building, No. 111 John Street.

October 22, 1930
Views: 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - Wall Street - Northwest.

Two views photographed in the general direction of City Hall Park from the above location, showing in the center the rising insurance zone. The structure under construction is the 35 story building, No. 1 Platt Street.

In the background are the Transportation, Woolworth and Municipal Buildings.

text:
120 Wall Street, (American Sugar Refining Building): South Street, west side, from Wall and Pine Streets, (general view southwestward).

A view towards the North (Hudson) River, viewing along Pearl Street from the above vantage point. Nestling in the center is Hanover Place and its India House. In the background appears the framework of the Maritime Exchange Building, the International Telephone Building, and the Standard Oil Building.

October 22, 1930

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - Wall Street - Southwest.

text:
South Street, at Coenties Slip, showing prominently the Seamens Church Institute as photographed across Jeannette Park. In the right background appears the white structure housing the American Sugar Refining Co. at No. 120 Wall Street.

February 1931

George L. Balgue, photo
title: Manhattan: South Street - Coenties Slip

text:
South Street, west side, south from Wall Street, showing prominently the buildings at the S. W. corner prior to their later demolition, as shown in View 2. This space will be utilized as a gas station. Note the smokestack atop the new U.S. Assay Office at Old Slip. Beyond is the cross atop the Seamens Church Institute at Coenties Slip.

1: March 27, 1931
2: Sept. 19, 1939

P. L. Sperr

South Street, west side, south from Wall Street, showing prominently the buildings at the S. W. corner prior to their later demolition, as shown in View 2. 2: Sept. 19, 1939

P. L. Sperr

Wall Street, south side, from and including South to and including Front Streets. This view also shows South Street, west side, from and including Wall Street to and including Jones Lane.

March 27, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

Wall Street, west from South Street, showing the easterly terminus of this important financial thoroughfare. At the right margin appears a portion of the American Sugar Refiners Bldg., No. 120 Wall Street. Beyond is the dominant Bank of Manhattan Bldg. at No. 40 Wall Street. The pyramidally roofed Bank of New York is overshadowed. The triangular apex of the Brown Bros. Bldg. juts out in the center. The remainder of this and the outstanding City Bank-Farmers Trust Co. Bldg. are obscured from view by the office structure under construction in the midground at Front Street.

March 27, 1931

P. L. Sperr

text:
Wall Street, north side, from but not including South Street to Water Street.

P. L. Sperr.

November 23, 1932.

In background is the
60 Wall Tower Bldg.

120 Wall Street, (American Sugar Refining Building), South Street, west side, from Wall to Pine Streets. (general view north-westward).

The new downtown skyline between Wall Street (left) and City Hall Park (right) that rose subsequent to 1928. The 60 Wall Tower (No. 70 Pine Street) is the latest addition and dominates everything else, being the third largest building in the World.

To the right of same are several new structures forming the insurance center. From left to right these are, the 22 story No. 1 Cedar Street, the 25 story Insurance Centre Building (No. 80 John Street), the 28 story No. 90 John Street, the 35 story No. 1 Platt Street) and the 26 story No. 111 John Street, (behind the smoke-stacks of the New York Steam Co. plant).

In the background, center and right respectively are the Transportation, Woolworth, Municipal, and Empire State Buildings.

1932

Wurts Brothers

Wall Street, west from, but not including South Street. Note the Bank of Manhattan Building, (40 Wall Street) towering over all.

October 14, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

East River, shore and skyline, as viewed in a northerly direction from pier 11, off South Street, at the foot of Jones Lane, showing (right) the American Sugar Refining Building (120 Wall Street) and the tower of the Bank of Manhattan Building (center left). About 1934.

Ewing Galloway.
title: East River - shore and skyline ; South ferry ; Williamsburg bridge.

text:
No. 120 Wall Street, (side view) at the N.W. corner of South Street. Actually this building faces onto South Street and is between Wall and Pine Streets. Also shown across the East River is the Brooklyn shore line south of the Brooklyn Bridge.

About 1935.

Ewing Galloway.

A general view of lower Manhattan, as seen from the Brooklyn Bridge, showing silhouetted against the western sky, No. 120 Wall Street; Farmers Loan and Trust Company; No. 60 Wall Street Tower; Bank of Manhattan and Singer Buildings. These, appear from left to right.

About 1936.

Gift of Dr. Michael Wishengrad, A.R.P.S.,

For another photo from the Brooklyn Bridge taken by Dr. Wishengrad, see 'Bridges - Brooklyn'

South Street, at the N.W. corner of Wall Street, showing a gas station there. South Street is at the left, and Wall Street is at the right. View 2 is photographed from Wall Street at Front Street and is towards the Downtown Sky Port at the East River's edge.

2: June 16, 1940

ASSUMING STREET TO BE NORTH AND SOUTH

South Street, at the N.W. corner of Wall Street, showing a gas station there. South Street is at the left, and Wall Street is at the right. View 2 is photographed from Wall Street at Front Street and is towards the Downtown Sky Port at the East River's edge.

1: May 8, 1940
2: June 16, 1940

P. L. Sperr

ASSUMING STREET TO BE NORTH AND SOUTH

General View of Lower Manhattan: the buildings, from left to right, are: 120 Wall Street, City Bank Farmers Trust, 60 Wall Tower, Bank of Manhattan, and Irving Trust Buildings. The views are across South Street.

Beecher Ogden

June 16, 1940
Views 1,2
title: General view - Lower Manhattan.
